State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China Direct CO2 hydrogenation into linear α-olefins presents a promising route in carbon-neutral chemical manufacture. This work systematically investigated the variable interplay between Reverse Water-Gas Shift (RWGS) and Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) during CO2 hydrogenation using model Na-Fe5C2 catalysts, combining dynamic/steady-state CO/CO2 hydrogenation performance, intrinsic kinetics and multiple characterization results. Na-Fe5C2 proves to be surface-enriched with FeO x sites over which RWGS readily proceeds. Meanwhile, CO2 conversion under integral reaction conditions is limited by the subsequent FTS step due to a lack of available FeC x sites. The catalyst performance is steered by the properties and relative quantities of the two different active sites. Na addition promotes the refresh of FeO x sites and β-elimination of alkyl intermediates over FeC x sites, but at the cost of inhibiting the surface fraction of FeC x sites and thus the single-pass CO2 conversion. These fundamental understandings will enlighten further development of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts with improved hydrocarbon yields. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Iron-based catalyst Alkali metal Active sites Intrinsic kinetics 1 Introduction Achieving carbon neutrality in the mid-21st century has become a global pursuit towards a green and sustainable future for human beings. In the aspect of carbon-neutral/negative chemical manufacturing, of special interest is disposing the energy and industry related CO2 emissions by renewable or discarded H2 to produce feedstock or commodity chemicals [1–4]. Linear α-olefins (LAO, C4+ linear terminal olefins) are indispensable raw material of high value-added fine chemicals including surfactants, plasticizers, premium synthetic lubricants, etc [5–7]. Therefore, direct synthesis of LAOs from CO2 hydrogenation has received widespread attention as among the most promising routes of catalytic CO2 upgrading [8,9]. The structure-performance relationship of Fe-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to LAOs has received much research attention [10–14]. These catalysts have iron oxide precursors, which are modified with alkali metal promoters, especially Na and K, and transition metal promoters, such as Zn, Mn and Al [15]. The precursor is pre-treated with H2 or CO prior to exposure in the CO2/H2 reactant atmosphere, during which periods it undergoes drastic structural evolution resulting in a complex fabrication of mixed iron oxide and iron carbide phases as the working catalyst [16]. The final composition and the structure of fabrication involving different phases of both iron and promoter elements depend on not only the initial composition of precursors but also the activation/reaction procedures [17,18]. It is generally believed that a Reverse Water-Gas Shift (RWGS) reaction converting CO2 into CO takes place over the iron oxide phases (in particular, Fe3O4); a subsequent Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) process of CO hydrogenation then proceeds over the iron carbide phases (especially χ-Fe5C2) phases, producing a spectrum of hydrocarbons [19,20]. The correlation between the relative contents of different active phases and CO2 hydrogenation performance, however, is not consistent in different studies: some concluded that the total hydrocarbon yields increase with the content of iron carbide phases in the working catalyst [21,22], others fail to identify definite correlations between the bulk phase content and the catalyst performance [23–25]. On the other hand, the single-pass CO2 conversion during CO2 hydrogenation over Fe-based catalysts has been found subject to the RWGS equilibrium, suggesting that the content of iron oxide phases is irrelevant with the hydrocarbon yields [26–28]. Since converting CO2 into hydrocarbons involves two types of active sites, the synergy between RWGS and FTS should be related with the relative quantities of the different surface sites over working-state Fe-based catalysts. Unfortunately, sophisticated surface structure and dynamics of the working catalyst hinder further clarifying the intrinsic activity of different iron phases and the communication between RWGS and FTS elementary reactions over different active sites. The surface FeC x /Fe3O4 ratio over a Na-Fe-Ce catalyst was found to be connected to the surface Na/Fe ratio during CO2 hydrogenation [29]. XPS measurements suggested that the addition of K into Fe-Al-O catalysts increases not only the FeC x /FeO x but also the Fe2+/Fe3+ surface ratios [30]. The Fe2+/Fe3+ ion pair is known to be crucial for the redox activation of CO2 over FeO x [31,32]. In addition to surface characterizations, global kinetics studies have been carried out on CO2 hydrogenation with Fe-based catalysts to shed lights on the intercoupling reaction pathways over different active sites [33,34]. Meiri et al. [35] established a Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) type kinetics model for CO2 hydrogenation over Fe-Al-O catalysts, which suggested that the oligomerization activity, i.e., conversion of light olefins to higher hydrocarbons, is crucial for the catalyst performance. Recently, Brübach et al. [36] proposed a LHHW type kinetics for CO2 hydrogenation over Fe/Al2O3 catalysts under the assumption of H-assisted CO2 and CO dissociation mechanisms for RWGS and FTS, respectively. As the RWGS and FTS rates are hardly related to the actual quantities of different active iron sites in the global kinetics models, the variable kinetic coupling modes could not be fully revealed. This work presents a systematic investigation on the coupled kinetics between RWGS and FTS reactions over FeO x and FeC x sites for CO2 hydrogenation to LAOs using model Na-Fe5C2 catalysts. The as-prepared catalyst precursors were pre-treated with CO into the bulk χ-Fe5C2 phase to minimize the difference in bulk iron carbide contents. Intrinsic kinetics analysis, dynamic and steady-state performance tests of CO/CO2 hydrogenations, combined with multiple characterizations techniques, help to elaborate the effects of the properties and the relative quantities of different interplaying iron sites that co-determine the catalytic performance. The revelation of inter-site synergy would consolidate the basis for promoting CO2 hydrogenation yields towards desired hydrocarbon products. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Catalyst preparation and activation Precursors to Na-Fe5C2 catalysts were first prepared through co-precipitation. Typically, 0.02 mol FeCl2 (Aladdin, ≥ 99.99 %) was dissolved in 60 ml ethylene glycol and the solution was transferred to a three-neck flask under N2 protection. The flask was kept at − 10 ℃ with 100 ml 0.8 M Na2CO3 (Sinopharm Chemical reagent, ≥ 99.8 %) solution added dropwise (1.2 ml/min) under vigorous stirring. The obtained suspension was aged at − 10 ℃ for 1 h followed by washing with 180 ml deionized water for 2, 3, 4, 8 or 15 times, respectively. The as-washed wet sample was dried in a vacuum oven at 333 K overnight and calcined under ambient air at 723 K for 4 h (ramping rate 2 K/min). The protocol produced catalyst precursors with different Na contents as identified by ICP-OES (Table S1). The precursors were then activated in-situ with CO to obtain the Na-Fe5C2 model catalysts. Typically, 100 mg catalyst precursor was loaded and 10 %CO/90 %Ar was introduced at 25 ml/min, 1 atm at 623 K for 5 h with a ramping rate of 2 K/min. In the following sections, the catalysts are denoted as Fe-xNa for brevity, where x is the weight percent of Na in the as-prepared catalyst precursor. 2.2 Characterizations For surface and bulk structural analysis, all air-sensitive samples were passivated by 1 %O2/Ar in-situ before being removed from the reactor. The element analysis was conducted on an Agilent 725 ICP-OES in which all the samples were digested in concentrated nitric acid at 120 ℃ for 6 h. Specific surface areas were determined by BET nitrogen adsorption using an automated ASAP 2020 Adsorption Analyzer (Micrometeritics Corp.), operated with liquid nitrogen at − 196 °C after evacuation of testing samples at 200 °C for 10 h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using a Cu Kα monochromatized radiation source (k = 1.5418 Å, accelerated voltage 40 kV, detector current 40 mA). The XRD patterns were collected in 10–80° with 0.02° interval and a residence time of 0.12 s. Laser Raman spectra were collected using a confocal Raman spectroscopy (LabRAM HR, Horiba J.Y., France) equipped with a visible 514.5 nm Ar+ laser and high-grade Leica microscopes (long working distance objective 50 ×, 20 ×, respectively). The exposure time was 80 s at an attenuated laser power of 2 mW on the samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer using a monochromatic Al-K radiation source (1486.6 eV, pass energy 20.0 eV) under ultrahigh vacuum (3.0 ×10−7 mbar). The C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV was taken as an internal standard. SEM images of the samples were taken using an FEI NOVA Nano SEM450 scanning electron microscope. TEM images were taken by a Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin electron microscope operated at 200 kV. The samples were ultrasonically dispersed in n-heptane and loaded on carbon-coated copper grids. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation and kinetic measurements The catalytic performance was evaluated in a stainless fixed-bed micro-reactor (7 mm inner diameter, 420 mm length). After in-situ activation using 10 % CO/Ar as previously mentioned in Section 2.1, the bed temperature was reduced to 603 K and the reactor was pressurized with the reactant mixed gas (20 %CO2/60 %H2/20 %N2 for CO2 hydrogenation; 20 %CO/60 %H2/20 %N2 for CO hydrogenation) to 1.5 MPa at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 15000 ml·g−1·h−1. Steady-state kinetics was measured using 5–20 mg catalyst (160–200 meshes, or 75–96 µm) diluted with inert graphite powders (200 mg in total). GHSVs from 280,000 to 700,000 ml·g−1·h−1 were used to ensure differential conditions (CO2 conversions < 10%) for intrinsic kinetics analysis. The external/internal diffusion effects had been ruled out following the same procedure as introduced in our previous work [37–39]. The gas-phase concentration of reactants and products was analyzed by on-line gas chromatography (GC). The composition of oil-phase liquid products was analyzed off-line by gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy (GC-MS) [12,40]. The selectivity to alcohols was typically < 2 wt% and can be omitted. The total carbon balance was c.a. 95 % in catalytic performance evaluation and c.a. 100 % in kinetic experiments. 2.4 Calculations In performance evaluation, the CO2 conversion ( X CO 2 ) was calculated as: (1) X CO 2 = ( Q in - Q out ) Q in × 100 % where Q in and Q out represent the volume flow rates (ml/h) of CO2 at the inlet and outlet, respectively. In kinetic measurements, the CO2 conversion was calculated as: (2) X CO 2 = ∑ i Q out , i N C , i Q in , CO 2 × 100 % where N C , i is the number of carbon atoms in product i. The RWGS reaction rate in terms of CO2 consumption( r CO 2 ) hydrogenation was calculated as: (3) r CO 2 ( mol · g cat - 1 · h - 1 ) = Q in X CO 2 22400 m cat in which m cat represents the mass of catalyst (g). The formation rate of hydrocarbon product i ( r HC , i ) was calculated as: (4) r HC , i ( mol · g cat - 1 · h - 1 ) = Q in X CO 2 S HC , i ( 1 - S CO ) 22400 m cat in which S CO represents CO selectivity and S HC , i is the selectivity to hydrocarbon product i in all hydrocarbons: (5) S CO = Q CO Q in · X CO 2 × 100 % (6) S HC , i = Q HC , i · C i Q in · X CO 2 · ( 1 - S CO ) × 100 % The rate of CO2 hydrogenation and product i formation during CO2 hydrogenation over iron-based catalyst j ( r i , j ) was described by a general power-law kinetics formula dependent on H2 and CO x (CO2 or CO) partial pressures: (7) r i,j = k i,j ·P H 2 α i,j ·P CO x β i,j where k i , j is the apparent rate constant, and α i , j and β i , j are the apparent reaction orders with respect to H2 and CO x , respectively. The reaction order with respect to H2 was obtained by varying P H 2 at a constant P CO 2 , while the reaction order with respect to CO x was measured by varying P CO x at a constant P H 2 . The apparent rate constant ( k i , j ) was expressed in an Arrhenius form: (8) k i,j = A i,j exp (- Ea i,j RT ) where A i , j and Ea i , j are the apparent pre-exponential factors and apparent activation barriers for carbon product i formation on catalyst j. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structure 3.1.1 Bulk structure The as-prepared catalyst precursors were dominated by the α-Fe2O3 crystalline phase with a Na content ≤ 0.7 wt%, and by the γ-Fe2O3 phase with Na contents of 2.8 and 4.4 wt% as indicated by XRD and Raman characterizations (Fig. S1). Characteristic diffraction peaks for NaCl were found in Fe-2.8Na and Fe-4.4Na precursors, where Cl was probably remnant from the FeCl2 ingredient [41]. Besides, TEM images (Figs. S2a-c) reveal a variation in morphology of the primary particles from rod-like (Na ≤ 0.7 wt%) to cube-like (Na ≥ 0.7 wt%), which is in line with the inferred crystalline phases. In addition to phase structure, the effect of Na on particle sizes, morphology and texture was further investigated by TEM and SEM. The average particle size increased with the Na content in catalyst precursors (Figs. S3). By applying the CO activation treatment, XRD ( Fig. 1a) shows that different iron oxide phases in the precursors had been completely reduced and carburized into χ-Fe5C2 (JCPDS, 36–1248), the acknowledged active phase for FTS [42,43]. The existence of the Fe3C crystalline phase can be excluded given the absence of its characteristic peaks at 37.6° and 49.1° (JCPDS, 65–2413). Consistent with this, Raman spectra (Fig. 1b) suggest no remaining oxide phases. In previous work, we had used Mössbauer spectroscopy to ascertain that Fe-based catalyst could be reduced and then fully carburized into χ-Fe5C2 under similar conditions [12,40,44]. Fig. 1a also indicates that the NaCl as observed in the Fe-4.4Na (precursor) was preserved after activation. In the mean time, a weak peak is observed to emerge at 31.7° in freshly-activated Fe-0.7Na. This is assigned to the major diffraction peak of NaCl, and it suggests aggregation of Na promoters during catalyst activation. In brief, despite the structural divergence in catalyst precursors, activation using 10 %CO resulted in a similar Na-modified χ-Fe5C2 bulk structure of Fe-Na, Fe-0.7Na and Fe-4.4Na. Fig. 1c and d show the XRD patterns and Raman spectra for the catalysts after CO2 hydrogenation. In spent Fe-4.4Na, three most prominent diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 at 30.1, 35.4 and 62.5° (JCPDS, 36–1451), respectively, are clearly observed (Fig. 1c). However, these features are difficult to identify in spent Fe-0.7Na and spent Fe. Consistent with the XRD results, peaks of the Eg, T2 g(2) and A1 g vibrational modes of Fe3O4 at 300 cm−1, 546 cm−1 and 655 cm−1, respectively, are only distinguishable in the Raman spectra of spent Fe-4.4Na (Fig. 1d). Furthermore, growth of particle sizes observed after the reaction (Fig. S2) agrees with the result of catalyst sintering during CO2 hydrogenation. On the other hand, the growth of specific surface areas together with the decrease of the total pore volumes (Table S2) after the reaction can be attributed to the formation of porous carbon, which will be discussed in Section 3.1.2. The characterization results indicate that the Na-Fe5C2 model catalysts were partially oxidized into bulk Fe3O4 during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, and such a process is promoted by Na. However, if alkali-promoted iron oxide catalyst precursors were activated by hydrogen or syngas, as having been done in many literatures [45–47], the freshly-activated catalysts contain iron oxides, metallic iron and iron carbides, which undergo further reduction and carburization during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. In such cases, the alkali promotion, by improving CO dissociation, increases the content of iron carbides and decreases that of iron oxides in the catalyst during the initial reaction stage. 3.1.2 Carbon deposition The Na promotion on CO adsorption and dissociation is related with increased catalyst coking [22,23]. Raman spectra provide information of the evolution of deposited carbon during activation and reaction. The D and G bands at ~1350 cm−1 and ~1590 cm−1, as shown in Fig. 1d, highlight the presence of deficient graphitic carbon deposition in all freshly-activated catalysts [48]. Moreover, the relatively high integrated D-to-G intensity ratios (I D/I G) suggest a highly-disordered nature of these carbon species. The disordered carbon on freshly-activated Fe-0.7Na and Fe-4.4Na were transformed into more ordered carbon species after CO2 hydrogenation as implied by the significantly decreased I D/I G values for the spent catalysts (Fig. 1d) [48,49]. In contrast, on the Na-free Fe catalyst, the carbon deposition remained in the disordered form after the reaction given the almost invariant I D/I G value. STEM-EDX mappings further suggest that the extent of carbon deposition after CO2 hydrogenation increased with Na addition (Fig. S4). For Fe and Fe-0.7 Na, the deposited carbon mainly grew in between the catalyst particles, whereas for Fe-4.4Na, carbon spread widely and covered catalyst particles. 3.1.3 Near-surface structure The oxidation of Na-Fe5C2 catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation in the near-surface regions was elucidated using XPS. The freshly-activated and spent catalysts were sputtered with Ar+ to eliminate the passivation layers covering the catalyst surface. The XPS peak at a binding energy (B.E.) of ca. 707.4 eV is attributed to carbidic iron species (FeC x ) and the shoulder peak centered at c.a. 711.2 eV is attributed to oxidic iron species. Comparing Fig. 2a and b, the surface ratios of Fe-C to Fe-O (FeC x /FeO x ) after the reaction clearly decreased. In addition, the characteristic peaks of FeC x downshift c.a. 0.4 eV from spent Fe to spent Fe-4.4Na catalysts, as can be expected due to the electron donation effect of Na.[50,51] Deconvolution of the Fe 2p XPS peaks indicate the co-presence of FeC x , Fe2+ and Fe3+ species with B.E.s of 707.4, 709.5 and 711.2 eV, respectively [52,53]. According to the deconvoluted peak areas, the surface FeC x /FeO x ratios (on an iron atom basis) were calculated. The introduction of 0.7 and 4.4 wt% Na decreased the FeC x /FeO x ratio from 0.38 to 0.36 and 0.32, respectively, for the samples subject to 0.5 min Ar+ sputtering. When increasing the sputtering duration to 2 min, the FeC x /FeO x ratios further increased and the addition of 0.7 and 4.4 wt% Na decreased the measured FeC x /FeO x values from 0.59 to 0.47 and 0.48, respectively. The XPS results with different sputtering durations, in accord with the XRD and Raman characterizations, confirm that Na enhanced the oxidation of FeC x species during CO2 hydrogenation. The intensified oxidation possibly arose from the stabilization effect of alkali metal compounds on the adsorbed oxygen that is dissociated from gas-phase oxidants CO2 and H2O [54]. 3.2 Intrinsic kinetics analysis To elaborate the variable kinetic interplays between RWGS and FTS in CO2 hydrogenation over Na-Fe5C2 catalysts, intrinsic kinetic studies were first conducted using Fe, Fe-0.7Na and Fe-4.4Na. The reversibility of the RWGS reaction and re-adsorption of hydrocarbon products could be neglected in the kinetic experiments due to under the differential conditions. The reaction pathways of CO2 hydrogenation, analyzed by varying the space velocity (Fig. S5), agrees with the widely recognized “tandem” pathway of CO2 hydrogenation regardless of the Na content: CO is first generated from RWGS and then serves as the feed for FTS [55,56]. In the following sections, the intrinsic RWGS and FTS kinetics are discussed separately. 3.2.1 Intrinsic RWGS kinetics with different Na contents Fig. 3 shows the Arrhenius plots for intrinsic RWGS rates over Fe, Fe-0.7Na and Fe-4.4Na in the temperature range of 573–613 K. An identical activation energy of RWGS of 66 kJ/mol was observed over all the three catalysts. Meanwhile, the pre-exponential factors, instructed by the intercepts, increased in the order of Fe-4.4Na < Fe < Fe-0.7Na. Since the activation energy suggests the same RWGS mechanism regardless of Na addition, the different pre-exponential factors could be assigned to different number of active sites for RWGS. The high intrinsic RWGS activity over Fe-0.7Na could be accounted for by a higher proportion of surface FeO x species as the XPS results implied (Fig. 2b and c). The suppressed intrinsic RWGS activity with over-addition of Na as in Fe-4.4Na was probably due to physical blocking of surface sites by saturated Na phases (implied by the emergence of NaCl in Fig. 1c) and increased carbon deposition (Figs. 1d and S4c). Fig. 4 shows the effects of reactant partial pressures on intrinsic RWGS rates. The reaction exhibited positive reaction orders with respect to both CO2 and H2. The CO2 reaction orders were almost independent of the temperature. Increasing the Na content to 0.7 wt% showed no effect on the CO2 reaction order, but a further increase to 4.4 wt% slightly lowered the reaction order by ~0.1. Decoration of Na into FeO x is believed to increase the surface basicity and enhance CO2 adsorption [41]. Since the r.d.s of RWGS over FeO x has proved to be removal of active O* by H2 [57], the improved CO2 adsorption ability barely contributed to overall RWGS rates. Instead, in the case of Fe-4.4Na, a strong CO2 adsorption increased the surface coverage of CO x , thus decreasing the CO2 reaction order. In contrast to CO2, the H2 reaction orders over all three catalysts increased with temperature, but decreased by ~0.1 with the addition of 0.7 or 4.4 wt% Na at 573 K. These observations could be explained by Na suppressing the H2-reduction of Fe3O4 [58] and thereby inhibiting the removal of O* during the RWGS catalytic cycle. The results also imply lower coverages of surface hydrogen species, e.g., H* or OH*, at higher temperatures. The effects of product CO on the intrinsic RWGS activity were also investigated in view of the reaction’s reversibility. To guarantee gathering reliable intrinsic kinetic information, CO was introduced into the feed stream stepwise to partially replace the internal standard N2 under differential conditions. As expected, the CO reaction orders for RWGS were negative over all three catalysts because of the WGS reaction (Fig. S6). An observed enhancement in the inhibitive effect of CO with increasing temperature is consistent with higher activation energy of WGS over FeO x (85 kJ/mol) [59] than RWGS (66 kJ/mol, this work) within the temperature range. With Na addition, the WGS reaction was further improved and it decreased the CO reaction order for RWGS. 3.2.2 Intrinsic FTS kinetics with different Na contents Fig. 5 illustrates the activation energy for hydrocarbons production as a function of the carbon number during CO2 hydrogenation. The activation energy values with respect to specific hydrocarbon products are listed with the standard deviations in Table S3. Our results show systematically higher activation barriers for primary olefins production than paraffins production, even though the O/P ratios of all hydrocarbon products were greater than 1. In practice, similar results have been presented for Fe-Mn in FTS [39]. The currently prevailing FTS mechanisms suggest that saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons are formed through hydrolysis and β-elimination of the same alkyl-like intermediates (e.g., -C n H2n+1-), respectively [60]. According to the Arrhenius equation, the reaction rate is determined by the pre-exponential factor, the activation energy, and the concentrations of reaction intermediates involved. Since the activation energy of an olefin is higher than that of a paraffin with the same carbon number, the pre-exponential factor or the concentrations of corresponding reaction intermediates for the olefins formation must be larger than that of the paraffins formation. In other words, the quantity of alkyl intermediates undergoing hydrolysis should be orders of magnitude smaller than that undergoing β-elimination, implying the difficulty of active H* approaching the alkyl intermediate. The addition of Na exhibited different kinetic influences on the production of paraffins and olefins. For paraffins, Na increased the activation barrier for CH4 production, showed negligible effects on the activation barrier for light paraffins production, whereas decreased the activation barrier for heavier paraffins production. With respect to olefins production, notably, Na addition significantly lowered the activation barriers, especially for the lighter olefins (Fig. 5b and c). This promotion effect of Na is usually explained by a modulation of the electronic structure of FeC x (as shown by XPS, Fig. 2b) that favors dehydrogenation of alkyls and C-C coupling [50,51,61]. Fig. 6 shows the effect of CO partial pressures on C1-C6 hydrocarbons production at 573 and 613 K. The detailed CO reaction orders with standard deviations are listed in Table S4. The production rates of all hydrocarbons depended positively on the CO partial pressure at 573 K, but negative CO orders for paraffins production were found over Na-promoted catalysts (Fe-0.7Na and Fe-4.4Na) at 613 K. These observed kinetic behaviors conform with the FTS mechanism in which saturated/unsaturated hydrocarbons are derived through hydrolysis/β-elimination of alkyl intermediates, which are generated by polymerization of CO-derived chain-growth monomers (e.g. -CH x -) [60]. Deriving heavier hydrocarbons involves combination of more monomers and are therefore more sensitive to the CO supply, as ascertained by a general trend of increasing CO reaction order with the carbon number. Furthermore, the reaction orders decreased with the increase of temperature or Na contents. The production of paraffins over Fe-0.7Na and that of all hydrocarbons over Fe-4.4Na under 613 K were inhibited by CO. The negative CO orders with the presence of Na promotion at higher temperatures indicate that the supply of carbon did not improve the formation of hydrocarbon intermediates (-C n H2n+1-) and chain-growth monomers (-CH x -). The dependence of FTS rates on H2 partial pressures offers more insights into the distribution of surface species during CO2 hydrogenation ( Fig. 7 and Table S5). Over all three catalysts, the H2 reaction orders were positive under both temperatures and ~0.5 higher at 613 K than 573 K. Additionally, contrary to the relatively lower CO reaction orders for paraffins formation (Fig. 6), the H2 reaction orders for paraffins formation were ~0.5 higher than those for olefins formation within experimental errors. The different H2 reaction orders between paraffins and olefins are consistent with the prevailing FTS mechanism in that the formation of C n H2n+2 and C n H2n from -C n H2n+1- consumes and generates H*, respectively. It could also be noticed that the increase of H2 reaction orders with the presence of Na promotion at the elevated temperature (Fig. 7e and f) is in correspondence to the decrease of CO reaction orders (Fig. 6e and f). Such a kinetic behavior further evidences a hydrogen-lean state over the FeC x sites under such conditions, so that the supply of hydrogen, rather than carbon, was kinetically-relevant for the formation of the hydrocarbon intermediates and the chain-growth monomers. It is generally assumed that Na-promoted iron carbide catalyst surface binds strongly with C*, O* or alkyl intermediates with the adsorption and dissociation of H2 inhibited [62,63]. However, in such a case, the H2 reaction orders would not increase upon Na addition. The increase of H2 reaction order upon Na addition at elevated temperatures, as shown in this work, suggests possible site competition between the surface CO-derived species and H* under the relatively low gas-phase carbon potentials in CO2 hydrogenation (typically H2/CO >15) [39,64,65]. Altogether, the intrinsic kinetics under authentic CO2 hydrogenation conditions provide experimental proofs to recent temperature-programmed and DFT studies on olefins desorption and C-C coupling over Na-promoted iron carbide catalysts [40,50,61]. In particular, the measured activation energy and reaction orders for hydrocarbons production reveal the driving force for the product spectrum to shift towards higher olefins over Na-modified Fe5C2 surfaces. 3.3 Induction period dynamics for CO/CO2 hydrogenation Comparative studies on the CO and CO2 hydrogenation performance over the Na-Fe5C2 catalysts were further conducted using reactant gases with H2/CO2 = 3/1 and H2/CO = 3/1 under the same operating conditions (603 K, 1.5 MPa and a space velocity of 15000 ml·g cat - 1 ·h - 1 ). The Na-Fe5C2 catalysts experienced induction periods of 5–10 h before their catalytic performance plateaued in both CO and CO2 hydrogenation (Figs. S7 and S8). Such induction periods are usually accompanied by the transformation of catalyst structure and improvement of catalytic performance [66]. Fig. 8 shows the dynamic evolution of WGS/RWGS and FTS activities during induction periods in CO/CO2 hydrogenation. The normalized activities of all the catalysts exhibited similar evolution within the first 10 h time on stream (T.O.S), that is, WGS/RWGS activities grew synchronously with FTS activities. After 10 h, the FTS activities declined except for CO hydrogenation on the Fe catalyst, which kept steady. Such a decline characteristic was more significant in CO2 hydrogenation than in CO hydrogenation. Moreover, the degrading FTS activities was accompanied by a slight decrease in RWGS activities in CO2 hydrogenation (after 15 h, Fig. 8b and c) but an increase of WGS activities in CO hydrogenation. The extent of such FTS activity degradation increased with the addition of Na in both CO and CO2 hydrogenation. The activity evolution at the later stage of induction periods can be mainly attributed to oxidation of FeC x , the active phase for FTS. Since Na improves re-oxidation of FeC x , the decline of FTS activity intensifies with increasing Na contents. Carbon deposition should not be a major contributor given that the decline of FTS activity was milder in CO hydrogenation, wherein the CO-rich, reductive atmosphere facilitates carburization while suppresses oxidation. Furthermore, the oxidation process generated FeO x as the active phase for WGS in CO hydrogenation, which could be responsible for the observed rise in WGS activities over the Na-promoted samples. However, the evolution of RWGS activities in CO2 hydrogenation was more complicated: The decline of FTS activities and ascent of RWGS activities was not synchronous. Instead, a slight decline of RWGS activities also occurred along with the decline of FTS activities. The inspection into the induction period dynamics indicates that while increasing FeO x improves WGS in CO hydrogenation, it does not necessarily promote RWGS in CO2 hydrogenation. The reason will be elaborated in the remainder of the article. 3.4 Steady-state CO/CO2 hydrogenation performance Table 1 summarizes the steady-state catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation over the Na-Fe5C2 catalysts at 30 h T.O.S. Different from the intrinsic kinetics, the Na-free sample exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (38.9 %), the lowest CO selectivity (13.8 %), and a high selectivity to light paraffins (CH4: 37.8 %, C2 0-C3 0: 10.5 %, O/P: 2.9). A slight increase of the Na content to 0.2 wt% did not noticeably vary the CO2 conversion and the CO selectivity; however, the product distribution was shifted significantly to higher hydrocarbons as reflected by the prominent change in the selectivities to CH4 and C8+, although the O/P ratio was relatively low (3.8). Over Fe-0.7Na, the CO2 conversion decreased to 35.5 % and the CO selectivity increased to 20.2 %. The hydrocarbon distribution was further altered towards higher olefins—the CH4 selectivity dropped to 21.7 %, the C4 =-C7 = and C8+ selectivities increased to 24.9% and 22.1 %, respectively, and the O/P ratio reached a remarkable value of 12.7. Detailed GC-MS analysis confirmed that the products in liquid oil-phase were mostly composed of long-chain LAOs (Fig. S9). Increasing the Na content to 4.4 wt% further increased the CO selectivity to 23.5 %, but barely affected the CO2 conversion and hydrocarbon product distribution. At the same time, the chain growth probability (α) of Anderson–Schulz–Flory distribution was found to increase from 0.38 to 0.48 with the Na content increased from 0 to 0.7 wt% and remained almost constant when further increasing the Na content to 4.4 wt% (Table 1). In all, the effects of Na on hydrocarbons selectivity plateaued at a not-high threshold level (0.7 wt%) which agrees with previous reports [67]. In our case, the surface Na species were likely saturated for Na contents > 0.7 wt% as implied by the emergence of bulk NaCl in XRD (Fig. 1a and c). It is worth pointing out that the equilibrium CO2 conversion of RWGS alone is 28 % under our given reaction conditions, in contrast to an over 70 % CO2 conversion taking all olefinic products into account [68]. In other words, the obtained 35–40 % CO2 conversion in CO2 hydrogenation was in effect enabled by consecutive consumption of CO in subsequent FTS. To quantify the relative activity of RWGS to FTS during steady-state CO2 hydrogenation, an approach-to-equilibrium factor of RWGS ( μ RWGS ) was used: (9) μ RWGS = P CO P H 2 O P CO 2 P H 2 · 1 K eq , RWGS where K eq , RWGS is the equilibrium constant of the RWGS reaction. As listed in Table 1, the high μ RWGS values of 0.79–0.86 indicate close-to-equilibrium states of the RWGS step as Fe-Zn-Na and Fe-Mn-Na catalysts under similar reaction conditions [26,28]. Na had no notable effect on μ RWGS at 603 K. We note here that the calculated μ RWGS signifies c.a. 5-fold faster rates of RWGS in the forward direction with respect to subsequent FTS over Na-Fe5C2 catalysts, leaving the latter reaction rate-limiting for net CO2 conversion. It can be concluded that the key to boost CO2 hydrogenation over Fe based catalysts is enhancing the FTS activity rather than the RWGS activity. To better understand the intrinsic performance of Na-Fe5C2 in catalyzing the FTS reaction, the freshly-activated catalysts were tested parallelly in CO hydrogenation with the H2/CO ratio (3:1) higher than optimal for FTS with Fe-based catalysts [69] but are closer to the CO2 hydrogenation conditions. The effects of Na on the FTS activity and hydrocarbon selectivity were highly consistent in CO and CO2 hydrogenation: Na promotion inhibited CH4 formation, improved chain growth and olefins production, but suppressed the overall FTS activity (Table S6). Na addition also improved the WGS activity as indicated by the increase of CO2 selectivity from 36.7 % to 41.4 % with the Na content increased from 0 to 4.4 wt%. Similar results have been reported for other alkali-promoted Fe-based catalysts in FTS [70,71]. Moreover, in CO hydrogenation where lower H2/CO ratios than in CO2 hydrogenation favors olefins formation, the O/P ratios of products were surprisingly lower than those in CO2 hydrogenation. Such a result is ascribed to enhanced re-adsorption and secondary hydrogenation of the primarily-formed olefins because of the > 90 % CO conversions and high olefin partial pressures. The comparison between CO and CO2 hydrogenation performance supports that the same active phases were involved in hydrogenation of CO/CO2 over Na-Fe5C2, namely FeC x for FTS and FeO x for WGS/RWGS. In addition, the high CO conversions obtained in CO hydrogenation indicate c.a. 2.5-fold higher intrinsic FTS activity over the Na-modified χ-Fe5C2 than it demonstrated under the CO2 hydrogenation conditions. This phenomenon, combined with the fact that FTS serves as the rate determination step (r.d.s) of CO2 hydrogenation, suggest a high surface FeO x to FeC x ratio under the strongly oxidative CO2 hydrogenation conditions [12,72–74]. Supports to this inference include XPS results of the spent catalysts after CO hydrogenation (Fig. S10), as well as different bulk compositions of spent iron-based catalysts after CO and CO2 hydrogenation reported previously [75,76]. Altogether, we argue that the dominating surface sites over Na-Fe5C2 under CO2 hydrogenation conditions is FeO x , making the overall CO2 hydrogenation performance sensible to the remaining FeC x sites. 4 Conclusions The interplays between the RWGS reaction over FeO x sites and the FTS reaction over FeC x sites have been elaborated for direct CO2 hydrogenation to linear α-olefins using Na-Fe5C2 model catalysts. The catalysts contained a χ-Fe5C2 bulk phase after activation, and underwent partial surface oxidation during CO2 hydrogenation. Surface FeO x species emerged in both CO/CO2 hydrogenation and its formation was promoted by Na addition. The CO2 activation process over the FeO x -relevant sites on Na-Fe5C2 with Na % < 4.4 wt% was implied to proceed via a common redox mechanism, which was promoted by moderate Na addition as the amount and reduction capability of active O* increase. For FTS, the primary formation of long-chain olefinic products is promoted by Na addition because of reduced activation barriers of β-elimination of alkyl intermediates and maximized surface coverages of carbon chain-growth monomer. Over-addition of Na decreased the available active sites for both RWGS and FTS because of the physical blockage of saturated Na species and carbon deposition. Comparison between dynamic and steady-state CO/CO2 hydrogenation performance suggested that large fractions of FeO x overlayers were present on the χ-Fe5C2-dominating bulk phase during CO2 hydrogenation. The overall RWGS rate related with the surface content of FeO x positively under differential conditions (CO2 conversion < 10 %) but negatively under integral conditions (CO2 conversion >10 %). In the latter case, the CO2 conversion rate was limited by the removal of CO from subsequent FTS, which depended on the supply of surface FeC x species. As the intrinsic activity of RWGS far exceeds that of FTS, kinetically or thermodynamically stabilizing FeC x against oxidation by efficient surface modification is the key to unlock the full potential of Fe-based catalysts towards maximized hydrocarbon yields. Our findings contribute to understanding the interplaying RWGS and FTS reactions over Fe-based catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation involving different types and quantities of iron sites. The presented work could potentially stimulate future development of multi-site CO2 hydrogenation catalysts through tailoring the quantities and properties of different surface sites so as to achieve the optimal inter-site synergy. coredata.dc:description: Direct CO2 hydrogenation into linear α-olefins presents a promising route in carbon-neutral chemical manufacture. This work systematically investigated the variable interplay between Reverse Water-Gas Shift (RWGS) and Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) during CO2 hydrogenation using model Na-Fe5C2 catalysts, combining dynamic/steady-state CO/CO2 hydrogenation performance, intrinsic kinetics and multiple characterization results. Na-Fe5C2 proves to be surface-enriched with FeO x sites over which RWGS readily proceeds. Meanwhile, CO2 conversion under integral reaction conditions is limited by the subsequent FTS step due to a lack of available FeC x sites. The catalyst performance is steered by the properties and relative quantities of the two different active sites. Na addition promotes the refresh of FeO x sites and β-elimination of alkyl intermediates over FeC x sites, but at the cost of inhibiting the surface fraction of FeC x sites and thus the single-pass CO2 conversion. These fundamental understandings will enlighten further development of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts with improved hydrocarbon yields.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding kinetically interplaying reverse water-gas shift and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis during CO2 hydrogenation over Fe-based catalysts
